awd_titl_txt: RAPID: STEM faculty support to address impacts from COVID-19 on Tribal Colleges and Universities Program institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. Expanding the STEM curricular offerings at these institutions expands the opportunities of their students to pursue challenging, rewarding careers in STEM fields, provides for research studies in areas that may be culturally significant, and encourages a community and generational appreciation for science and mathematics education. The sustainability of STEM instructional capacity gains is significantly enhanced by retaining the talent of credentialed STEM faculty. This project aligns directly with that goal.

The COVID-19 pandemic caused major disruptions to institutions of higher education. For tribal colleges and universities, whose core operating funds are directly aligned with student enrollment, drops in enrollment equate to loss of funding. To mitigate against detrimental pandemic-related effects on STEM instructional capacity, this award will support the salary and professional development of one full-time STEM faculty member at Sitting Bull College. This TCUP STEM Faculty award is intended to help maintain Sitting Bull College’s STEM program as the college recovers from the deleterious impact of the pandemic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The challenges of STEM instruction for lab based courses during the pandemic identified an important need at Sitting Bull College. It underscored the fact that the institution was ill prepared to handle alternative means of instruction to meet the challenges created by the pandemic. using the Biology program as its test sample, SBC enhanced the program by finding innovative ways to teach curriculum. The strategic aim was to make the program relevant to students during the pandemic period, given enrollment numbers were rapidly declining for the program courses because of laboratory requirements and face to face needs. A number of strategies were implemented to improve student participation and outcomes in the program These included: online laboratory options for instruction, increasing the number of course sections and times specific courses were offered, using DIY kits as instruction materials for students to do labs and practicum at home; providing an online space for students to communicate with each other and the course instructors, and securing the biology faculty position so it was not impacted and removed because of the low enrollment numbers in biology. .

SBC was able to use adaptive tools and approaches to safeguard a proven foundation of STEM recruitment at the disposal of TCUs. The number of student at SBC enrolled in the program courses has remained steady because of this adaptive approach. This secured the continuation of Native American students wjo are taking STEM courses because we overcame a major obstacle that will certainly have forced students to chose other less combersome programs. Our enrollment numbers show a positively effect our Native American students have when they perceive STEM courses. The strategies increased cmpletion rates for our students and reduced significantly the number of students whop dropped out because of lack of access to course resources in the program.

The key value of this project is that it provided a plethora of tested tools and strategies that work well in situations where traditional face to face oinstruction is hampered. The tools to address obstacles and engagement students in STEM was developed from student demands and reasons they could not complete the courses during the pandemic. .By keeping students in class and learning, they were developing knowledge. The strategies also took into account the indigenous perspectives of how knowledge was traditionally transferred and it was determined this strategies fit with what is found in the literature.. Over 54 students enrolled in courses in the program which is significantly highr than the 45 students targeted for the project. Eight biology courses were taught during the project period. .

Finally the project requested and extension to use up remaining funds to wrap up important aspects of the project. Supply chain issues around the purchase of supplies and materialls to meet project objectives required the project use resources from other programs.  Primarily, the request was made so materials and supplies which were borrowed from other programs and departments could be purchased and returned to these units This was completed within ythe requested period.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/02/2024
Modified by: Mafany Ndiva Mongoh
